Award.AwardTitle: International Education and Training for U.S. Students in Association with a COSMIC Workshop in Taiwan for April 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal provides funding to support travel expenses for a group of U.S. students to attend the annual FORMOSAT-3/COSMIC Data Users and Science Workshop in Taiwan. In a successful international collaboration involving primarily Taiwan and the U.S., a global system of GPS satellites has been launched, and the data from them is used to support global weather prediction, climate monitoring, and space weather forecasting. Numerous international agencies make use of data from these satellites, and the users meet each year to discuss their work. On this occasion there will also be a student conference for students to present their work and to meet counterparts from other countries. Up to eleven students from across the U.S. will be supported for the trip, and those will be recruited by wide publication of the opportunity to participate.

The workshop as well as the student conference will include research presentations and workshop discussions on the data obtained from the satellites and the way it is being analyzed to improve weather forecasting. Sharing of this information among participants from a number of countries will promote progress in the field and enable the resolution of ever-more challenging atmospheric problems. The capability provided by the satellites and the data that they yield has significant social benefit by improving weather forecasting capabilities. The Radio Occultation method used here is not yet well known so exposure to the workshops should help to publicize the tool. Participation in the meetings, technical tours and workshops by eleven U.S. students will contribute to their professional development and establish productive relationships with colleagues, particularly in East Asia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The original focus of this project was to provide U.S. graduate and undergraduate students the opportunity to travel to Taipei, Taiwan during 9-17 April 2011 and participate in the Fifth FORMOSAT-3/COSMIC Data Users’ Workshop and International Conference on GPS Radio Occultation (ICGPSRO) (http://www.nspo.org.tw/5th_FS3WS/index.html). Participants attended the 3-day conference as full attendees to lectures and breakout sessions, gaining valuable exposure to world-class international scientists and research.

The award provided funding to support all travel expenses for the 10 U.S. students. The intent was to allow these students, as early-career future scientists, a professional-level experience in international collaboration and cultural exchange. This type of cultural understanding and collaborative skill development are crucial for future generations of U.S. scientists to succeed in the environment of continued globalization of science and technology. 

The student portion began with a joint U.S.-Taiwan student conference, organized in collaboration with National Central University (NCU), with students from both countries participating in presentations at the NCU campus in Jhongli City. Each student (18 Taiwanese and 10 U.S.) gave a scientific talk and discussed the objectives of their research. The U.S. students were also given the opportunity to co-chair these sessions with Taiwanese students. Students evaluated each other on the clarity of the presentations and knowledge of subject matter.

As a component of this workshop/conference, a student poster competition was organized with U.S. and Taiwanese students presenting their research to all conference attendees. Students received direct feedback and were formally judged by senior scientists in categories that included originality, comprehension, and clarity in presentation. Awards were given at a formal ceremony during the last day of the workshop. Links to the student posters can be found at http://www.cosmic.ucar.edu/taiwan2011/abstracts.html.

 Students also had the opportunity to tour the Satellite Integration & Testing (I&T) Building and Satellite Control Center at the National Space Organization (NSPO) in Hsinchu City, Taiwan, and met with NSPO staff and researchers.

 U.S. and Taiwanese students also participated in a variety of cultural activities together, spending one-half day at the National Palace Museum in Taiwan, taking a Tai Chi class at NCU, and on informal tours of Taiwan's cultural monuments and night markets. The students, and a few international senior scientists traveled to Hualien City for an overnight trip to the Taroko Gorge National Park.

 In November 2011, a reprogramming request was approved to allow for remaining funds to be used to support U.S. students to travel to Boulder CO, during 30 October-1 November 2012 and participate in the Sixth FORMOSAT-3/COSMIC Data Users’ Workshop.

 Both the 2011 and 2012 opportunities were announced via numerous mailing lists that included U.S. universities, AMS, and AGU. A competitive selection process, based on specific criteria, was used to screen the applicants. In 2011, the chosen U.S. students were from diverse regions and educational backgrounds, such as the University of Puerto Rico, San Francisco State University, University of Colorado Boulder, Purdue University, Rutgers University, Florida Institute of Technology, and University of California Davis. In 2012, the chosen U.S. students were from the Colorado State University, Purdue University, and the University of Hawaii.
